case_name: Indian Molasses Co. Private Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 395 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 21, 1955, of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 21, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1954.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court on November 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: with the special leave of this Court granted on November 9, 1956, against the judgment of the High Court

facts.text: Appellant is Indian Molasses Co. Private Ltd., Calcutta, referred to as assessee Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Molasses Co. Private Ltd., Calcutta hereinafter called the assessee Company , have brought this appeal

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether payments by assessee Company constitute expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law referred to the High Court was Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, and on a true companystruction of the Trust Deed, dated 16th September, 1948, and the Policy dated the 13th January, 1949, the payments made by the assessee Company and referred to in paragraph 4 above companystitute expenditure within the meaning of that word in section 10 2 xv of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The question was answered in the negative.

facts.text: John Bruce Richard Harvey was Managing Director of assessee Company in 1948.

anchor.surface_text: One John Bruce Richard Harvey was the Managing Director of the assessee Company in 1948.

facts.text: Harvey served the Company for 13 years by 1948 and was due to retire at age 55 on September 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He had by then served the Company for 13 years, and was due to retire at the age of 55 years on September 20, 1955.

facts.text: Company had obligation to provide pension to Harvey after retirement.

anchor.surface_text: There was, it appears, an agreement by which the Company was under an obligation to provide a pension to Harvey after his retirement.

facts.text: On September 16, 1948, Company executed Trust Deed in favour of three trustees.

anchor.surface_text: On September 16, 1948, the Company executed a Trust Deed in favour of three trustees to whom the Company paid a sum

facts.text: Company paid trustees £8,208-19-0 (Rs. 1,09,643) initially and undertook to pay annually Rs. 4,364 (£326-14 sh.) for six consecutive years.

anchor.surface_text: to whom the Company paid a sum of pound 8,208-19-0  Rs. 1,09,643  and further undertook to pay annually Rs. 4,364  pound 326-14 sh.  for six companysecutive years

facts.text: Trustees to hold sums to take out deferred annuity policy on life of Harvey for £720 per annum from superannuation.

anchor.surface_text: and the trustees agreed to execute a declaration of trust. The trustees undertook to hold the said sums upon trust to spend the same in taking out a deferred -Annuity Policy with the Norwich Union Life Insurance Society in the name of the trustees but on the life of Harvey under which pound 720 per annum were payable to Harvey for life from the date of his superannuation.

facts.text: Alternative provision for joint annuity to Harvey and Mrs. Harvey of £558-1-0 per annum, or £611-12-0 to Mrs. Harvey if Harvey dies before 55.

anchor.surface_text: It was also provided in the deed that numberwithstanding the main clause the trustees would, if so desired by the assessee Company, take out instead a deferred longest life policy, with the said Insurance Company, in their names, but in favour of Harvey and Mrs. Harvey for an annuity of pound 558-1-0 per annum payable during their joint lives from the date of Harveys superannuation and during the lifetime of the survivor, provided further that if Harvey died before he attained the age of 55 years the annuity payable to Mrs. Harvey would be pound, 611-12-0 during her life.

facts.text: Trustees took out policy on January 12, 1949 (question mentions 13th).

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of these presents, the trustees took out a policy on January 12, 1949.

facts.text: Policy benefits: £563-5-8 p.a. if both alive on Sept 20,1955; £720 if Mrs. dies first; £645 if Harvey dies first.

anchor.surface_text: Amount per annum of deferred Annuity pound 563-5-8 p. a. if both Mr. and Mrs. Harvey be living on September 20,1955. pound, 720-0-0 p. a. if Mrs.Harvey should die before September 20, 1955, leaving Harvey surviving her. pound, 645-0-0 p. a. if Harvey should die before September 20, 1955, leaving Mrs. Harvey surviving him.

facts.text: Special provision: Trustees entitled to surrender annuity on Sept 20,1955 for £10,169 with notice.

anchor.surface_text: Provided the companytract is in force and unreduced, the Grantees  i. e., the trustees  shall be entitled to surrender the Annuity on the Option Anniversary  i.e., Sept. 20, 1955  for the Capital sum of pound 10,169 subject to written numberice of the intention to surrender being received by the Directors of the Society within the thirty days preceding the Option Anniversary.

facts.text: Assessee Company paid initial sum and yearly premia for some years before Harvey died.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company paid the initial sum and the yearly premia for some years before Harvey died.

facts.text: In assessment years 1949-50, 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53, claimed deduction of sums under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment years 1949-50, 1950-51, 1651-52 and 1952-53, it claimed a deduction of these sums from its profits or gains under s. 10 2 xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Claim disallowed by Department, Appellate Tribunal, and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was disallowed by the Department and the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal held no expenditure at all, as money could revert to Company if both Harveys die before 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that it was number necessary to decide if the expenditure was wholly or exclusively for the purposes of the Companys business, and if so, whether it was of a capital nature, because in the Tribunals opinion there was numberexpenditure at all.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 5, 1959 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 5. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-The Indian Molasses Co. Private Ltd.

facts.text: High Court regretted limited scope of question, as other issues like capital/revenue remain for Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court numbericed the limited scope of the question, and pointed out that the Tribunal had stated at the end of the Statement of the Case In the event of the High Court holding that there was an expenditure in this case

facts.text: Order of assessment passed as far back as 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The order of assessment was passed as far back as 1952

facts.text: Supreme Court holds payments do not constitute expenditure under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the question was companyrectly answered by the Calcutta High Court.

facts.text: Harvey died before September 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: before Harvey died.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, and on a true construction of the Trust Deed, dated 16th September, 1948, and the Policy dated the 13th January, 1949, the payments made by the assessee Company and referred to in paragraph 4 above constitute expenditure within the meaning of that word in section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in respect of which a claim for deduction can be made, subject to the other conditions mentioned in that clause being satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, and on a true construction of the Trust Deed, dated 16th September, 1948, and the Policy dated the 13th January, 1949, the payments made by the assessee Company and referred to in paragraph 4 above constitute expenditure within the meaning

issues.text: Whether there was an expenditure within the meaning of section 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  xv  was analysed by the learned Chief Justice in these words It will be noticed that three ingredients of the clause lie on the surface of its language. In order that a deduction may be claimed under its provisions it must be proved first that there was an expenditure

issues.text: Whether there is a possibility of a resulting trust in favour of the assessee Company such that the money has not been spent irretrievably

anchor.surface_text: possibility of there being a resulting trust in favour of the Company, then the money has not been spent, i. e., paid out or away,

issues.text: Whether the assessee Company's liability was contingent or merely depending upon a contingency
Whether the expenditure was in the nature of capital expenditure

anchor.surface_text: secondly, that the expenditure was not in the nature of a capital expenditure- I am leaving aside the personal expenses-and, thirdly, that it was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the assessees business

issues.text: Whether the expenditure was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the assessee's business

anchor.surface_text: thirdly, that it was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purposes of the assessees business-I am leaving out profession or vocation.

issues.text: Whether the question referred can be answered without reference to the other ingredients of clause (xv)

anchor.surface_text: Whether the question can be answered in the bland form it is posed, is a matter to which we will have to address ourselves presently.

arguments.claim: There was no expenditure at all because if both Mr. and Mrs. Harvey die before September 20, 1955, payments revert via resulting trust to the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that it was not necessary to decide if the expenditure was wholly or exclusively for the purposes of the Companys business, and if so, whether it was of a capital nature, because in the Tribunals opinion there was no expenditure at all. The reason why the Tribunal held this way may be stated in its own words Clauses  1  and  II  do not contain any provision having a material bearing upon Clause  111 . Therefore if it happens that both Mr. and Mrs. Harvey die before 20th September, 1955, all the payments till made through the Trustees to the Insurance Society will come back to the Trustees and as there is not the slightest trace of any indication anywhere that the Trustees should have any beneficient interest in these moneys, there would be a resultant trust in favour of the Company in respect of the moneys thus far paid out.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat a companytract by which in companysideration of the payment by a person of a weekly premium, a sum certain was payable to him on his attaining the

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees that possibility of resulting trust means money not irretrievably spent.

arguments.claim: Payments constitute expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) as claimed deduction in assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company paid the initial sum and the yearly premia for some years before Harvey died. In the assessment years 1949-50, 1950-51, 1651-52 and 1952-53, it claimed a deduction of these sums from its profits or gains under s. 10 2 xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat a companytract by which in companysideration of the payment by a person of a weekly premium, a sum certain was payable to him on his attaining the

arguments.court_reasoning: No expenditure due to contingencies allowing reversion.

arguments.claim: Arrangement is provision for gratuity without written agreement, hence not effective expenditure; follows Atherton v. British Insulated.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that in the absence of a written agreement covering the conditions of service, remuneration, etc., the arrangement could only be taken as a provision for a gratuity, more so as there was a provision in the deed of trust for payment of an annuity to Mrs. Harvey in the event of Harveys demise.

arguments.claim: Payment is ex gratia of capital nature due to trust intervention; follows Atherton.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner considered that in the absence of an agreement the payment must be regarded as an ex gratia payment of a capital nature, so long as the trust intervened.

arguments.claim: Two contingencies lead to resulting trust: both die before 1955 or Mrs. dies first without provision; money reverts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court analysed the terms of the deed of trust, and pointed out that there were two contingencies in which money was likely to revert to the assessee Company. The first contingency was if both Harvey and Mrs. Harvey died before September 20, 1955.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat a companytract by which in companysideration of the payment by a person of a weekly premium, a sum certain was payable to him on his attaining the

arguments.court_reasoning: Correct on first contingency; error on second as policy covers it, but surrender option and cl III still apply.

arguments.claim: No instant necessity, not for business purpose of instant character, possibility of resulting trust means no expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then observed in addition that there was no instant necessity for the expenditure, no was the money laid out for a business purpose of an instant character, no did it bring in a present asset which would always remain an asset in that form, the money having gone for ever.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat a companytract by which in companysideration of the payment by a person of a weekly premium, a sum certain was payable to him on his attaining the

arguments.claim: Question covers only whether expenditure, not other grounds; strict construction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court noticed the limited scope of the question, and pointed out that the Tribunal had stated at the end of the Statement of the Case In the event of the High Court holding that there was an expenditure in this case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: business purpose of an instant character, number did it bring in a present asset which would always remain an asset in that form, the money having gon

arguments.court_reasoning: Court notes limited scope but proceeds on it.

arguments.claim: Even assuming expenditure, it is to meet contingent liability, not deductible.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Meyer contended that language entitled him to argue not only that there had been no expenditure in fact at all, but also that even assuming that there bad been an expenditure in the sense of a physical spending, still the expenditure was not such as could be claimed as an allowance under the clause against the profits of the relevant accounting year in view of the fact that it was, in any event, an expenditure made to meet a contingent liability.

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability contingent, not merely depending on contingency.

arguments.claim: Object to enlarging scope of question beyond Tribunal's single ground.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. Iyengar, who appeared on behalf of the assessee, objected to the scope of the question being so enlarged and he referred to the appellate order of the Tribunal which had proceeded on a single ground.

arguments.claim: Payment of pension is revenue expenditure; lump sum to rid recurring liability also revenue; actual payment made per dictionary meaning; Ch IX-B applies.

anchor.surface_text: The main points urged on behalf of the assessee Company are that payment of pension is an expenditure of a revenue character and so also the payment of a lump sum to get rid of a recurring liability to pay such pension. This is illustrated from some English cases, and reference is made also to Ch. IX-B of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: hat a companytract by which in companysideration of the payment by a person of a weekly premium, a sum certain was payable to him on his attaining the

arguments.court_reasoning: Ch IX-B irrelevant; expenditure requires irretrievability, absent here.

arguments.claim: Expenditure means laying out for accrued liability, not contingent; present arrangement is setting apart for contingent liability.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the Department is that by expenditures meant a laying out of money for an accrued liability and not for a contingent liability, which contingency may or may not take place that the present arrangement was only a setting apart of money for a Contingent liability and till the liability became real, there was no expenditure.

arguments.claim: Insurance expenditure not contingent as probabilities actuarially estimated.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company, however, contends that expenditure on insurance is not contingent, because though the contingency relates to life and depends on it, the probabilities are great being estimated on actuarial calculations and the expenditure is real.

arguments.court_reasoning: Insurance cases irrelevant; liability itself contingent.

arguments.claim: Expenditure means irretrievable paying out or away; here contingencies (surrender, both deaths) mean resulting trust possible, no expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the question was correctly answered by the Calcutta High Court.

arguments.claim: s.10(2)(xv) has three ingredients: (1) expenditure exists, (2) not capital, (3) wholly for business; question only on (1).

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  xv  was analysed by the learned Chief Justice in these words It will be noticed that three ingredients of the clause lie on the surface of its language. In order that a deduction may be claimed under its provisions it must be proved first that there was an expenditure

arguments.claim: Indian s.10(2)(xv) in pari materia with English r.1(a) Sch D; English cases aids with caution.

anchor.surface_text: This section, though it enacts affirmatively what is stated in the negative form in the English statute, is substantially in pari materia with the English enactment and would have justified our considering the English authorities as aids to the interpretation thereof

arguments.claim: Distinction between contingent liability (not deductible) and payment depending on contingency; here liability contingent.
Ch IX-B ss.58R,58S,58V irrelevant as allowance not under them.

holdings.text: The payments made by the assessee Company do not constitute expenditure within the meaning of section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Money not paid out irretrievably due to possibilities of resulting trust under policy clauses (surrender option and clause III for both nominees dying before option date), making it merely set apart for contingency.

holdings.text: Section 10(2)(xv) requires proof of three ingredients for deduction: (1) existence of expenditure, (2) not in nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses, (3) laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for business purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 2  xv  was analysed by the learned Chief Justice in these words It will be noticed that three ingredients of the clause lie on the surface of its language. In order that a deduction may be claimed under its provisions it must be proved first that there was an expenditure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual analysis of clause language, quoting High Court approvingly; question limited to first ingredient.

holdings.text: Expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) means money paid out or away irretrievably.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary primary meaning of 'spending' as paying out or away; must be irrevocable to qualify as expenditure.

holdings.text: Possibility of resulting trust in favour of assessee Company means money has not been spent or paid out irretrievably.

anchor.surface_text: If this condition be not fulfilled and there is a possibility of there being a resulting trust in favour of the Company, then the money has not been spent, i. e., paid out or away,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy terms (special provision for surrender and cl. III for repayment of premiums if both nominees die before option anniversary) create reversion possibility via resulting trust.

holdings.text: The assessee Company's liability was contingent and not merely depending upon a contingency.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction affirmed from Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen; here liability itself contingent on survival to vesting date, not accrued in praesenti.

holdings.text: The referred question can be answered without deciding the other ingredients of section 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: Whether the question can be answered in the bland form it is posed, is a matter to which we will have to address ourselves presently.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question framed narrowly on existence of expenditure; other issues (capital/revenue, business purpose) left to Tribunal as per reference scope.

holdings.text: Section 10(2)(xv) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 is substantially in pari materia with Rule 1(a) of Schedule D to English Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This section, though it enacts affirmatively what is stated in the negative form in the English statute, is substantially in pari materia with the English enactment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmative Indian form equivalent to English negative; justifies cautious use of English authorities.

holdings.text: Provisions of Chapter IX-B (ss. 58R, 58S, 58V) do not apply to the payments as claimed allowance under section 10(2)(xv).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowance claimed under cl.(xv), not falling within superannuation fund provisions; irrelevant to whether expenditure occurred.

precedents.citation: Allahabad Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal 1 1954 S.C.R. 195.

anchor.surface_text: because it felt that if this Court in Allahabad Bank Ltd. v. Com- missioner of Income-tax, West Bengal  1  was able to decide whether a particular outlay was expenditure without reference to the other ingredients of cl.  xv , the same

precedents.case_name: Allahabad Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: deciding whether a particular outlay was expenditure without reference to the other ingredients of cl. xv
precedents.cited_holding: contributions on trust for payment of pensions to employees were held not to be expenditure because on the original trust failing the money was deemed to be held by the trustees on a resulting trust for the benefit of the maker

precedents.citation: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables, Ltd. 1 1925 10 Tax Cas. 155.

anchor.surface_text: Following, therefore, the case in Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables, Ltd.  1  and distinguishing Hancock v. General Reversionary and Investment Co. Ltd.  2 , the claim for deduction was rejected by the Income-tax Officer.

precedents.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: provision for gratuity or pension fund is capital expenditure

precedents.citation: Hancock v. General Reversionary and Investment Co. Ltd. 2 1918 7 Tax Cas. 358.

anchor.surface_text: Following, therefore, the case in Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables, Ltd.  1  and distinguishing Hancock v. General Reversionary and Investment Co. Ltd.  2 , the claim for deduction was rejected by the Income-tax Officer.

precedents.case_name: Hancock v. General Reversionary and Investment Co. Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: single payment to purchase annuity in lieu of recurring pension is revenue expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: sum paid in purchasing the annuity was allowed as a deduction

precedents.citation: Smith v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England and Wales 1 1914 3 K. B. 574 6 Tax Cas. 477.

anchor.surface_text: It has been ruled under the English statute that sums paid to an employee as pension or gratuity are deductible as money laid out and expended for the purpose of trade, profession or vocation. See Smith v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England and Wales  1 .

precedents.case_name: Smith v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England and Wales
precedents.cited_proposition: sums paid to an employee as pension or gratuity are deductible

precedents.citation: Rowntree, Co. Ltd. v. Curtis 3 1925 1 K. B. 328 8 Tax Cas. 678.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, a sum which a companypany put into a fund for the relief of invalidity, etc., was held number to be an admissible deduction, and the case last cited was distinguished. See Rowntree, Co. Ltd. v. Curtis  3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: sum put into fund for invalidity relief not deductible

precedents.citation: Vallambrosa Rubber Co. v. Farmer 2 1910 5 Tax Cas. 529.

anchor.surface_text: Viscount Cave, L. C., recalled the test laid down in a rough way by Lord Dunedin in Vallambrosa Rubber Co. v. Farmer  2   at p. 192  that, capital expenditure is a thing that is going to be spent once and for all and income expenditure is a thing which is going to recur every year

precedents.cited_proposition: rough test for capital vs income expenditure
precedents.cited_holding: capital expenditure is spent once and for all, income recurs yearly

precedents.citation: Morgan Crucible Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1 1932 2 K. B. 185 17 Tax Cas. 311, 317.

anchor.surface_text: Again, in Morgan Crucible Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1 , the payment to an insurance companypany to take out a policy was held number to be an admissible deduction.

precedents.case_name: Morgan Crucible Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: payment to insurance company for pension policy acquires capital asset, not deductible

precedents.citation: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale 1 1932 1 K. B. 124 16 Tax Cas. 253.

anchor.surface_text: if the payment of a lump sum closes the liability to make repeated and periodic payments in the future, it may generally be regarded as a payment of a revenue character  Anglo-Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale   1 ,

precedents.case_name: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale
precedents.cited_proposition: lump sum payment closing future periodic payments is revenue

precedents.citation: Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford 2 1948 30 Tax Cas. 496.

anchor.surface_text: The case which illustrates this distinction is Peter Merchant Ltd. v. Stedeford  2 . No doubt, that case was decided under the system of Income-tax laws prevalent in England, but the, distinction is real.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between actual liability in praesenti and contingent liability de futuro

precedents.citation: Alexander Howard Co. Ltd v. Bentley 3 1948 30 Tax Cas. 334.

anchor.surface_text: We may here refer to two other cases. In Alexander Howard Co. Ltd v. Bentley  3 , a business of blouse and gown manufacture was carried on by one A. C. Howard.

precedents.case_name: Alexander Howard Co. Ltd v. Bentley
precedents.cited_proposition: redemption payment for annuity to non-employee (wife) is capital
precedents.cited_holding: sum paid in redemption of the annuity was not properly allowable as a deduction
